content.title: Pheochromocytoma
content.summary: Rare catecholamine-secreting tumor arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla causing episodic hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations
key_points: Rule of 10s: 10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% extra-adrenal (paraganglioma), 10% familial
Classic triad: Episodic headache, sweating, palpitations with hypertension
Diagnosis: Plasma free metanephrines (most sensitive) or 24-hr urine metanephrines
Imaging: CT or MRI after biochemical confirmation; MIBG scan for localization/metastases
Genetic testing recommended for all patients (30-40% have germline mutations)
Paragangliomas are extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas (sympathetic or parasympathetic ganglia)
content.statement: Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla causing potentially life-threatening hypertension, requiring biochemical confirmation before imaging and meticulous preoperative preparation with alpha-blockade before surgical resection.

explanation.intuition: Pheochromocytomas are tumors that produce adrenaline and noradrenaline. When these catecholamines are released in surges, patients experience the 'fight or flight' response - rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, sweating, and anxiety - but inappropriately and unpredictably.
explanation.key_insight: The 'pheo' adage 'alpha before beta' is life-saving. Blocking beta-receptors before alpha allows unopposed alpha-mediated vasoconstriction during catecholamine surge, causing dangerous hypertensive crisis. Always alpha-block first for 10-14 days before surgery.
explanation.technical_details: Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine) are metabolized to metanephrines (metanephrine, normetanephrine) by COMT. These metabolites are continuously produced by tumor tissue and are more sensitive/specific for diagnosis than parent catecholamines. Hereditary syndromes (MEN2, VHL, SDH mutations, NF1) account for 30-40% of cases.

definitions_glossary.pheochromocytoma: Catecholamine-secreting tumor arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla
definitions_glossary.paraganglioma: Extra-adrenal catecholamine-secreting tumor from sympathetic or parasympathetic ganglia
definitions_glossary.chromaffin_cells: Neuroendocrine cells that synthesize, store, and release catecholamines
definitions_glossary.metanephrines: Catecholamine metabolites (metanephrine, normetanephrine) used for diagnosis
definitions_glossary.plasma_free_metanephrines: Most sensitive biochemical test for pheochromocytoma (96-100% sensitivity)
definitions_glossary.mibg_scan: Metaiodobenzylguanidine scintigraphy for functional imaging and metastasis detection
definitions_glossary.alpha_blockade: Phenoxybenzamine or doxazosin used preoperatively to control hypertension
definitions_glossary.beta_blockade: Added AFTER alpha-blockade to control tachycardia; propranolol or atenolol
definitions_glossary.hypertensive_crisis: Severe acute hypertension that can occur with tumor manipulation or beta-blockade without alpha
definitions_glossary.men2: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2; RET mutation associated with pheochromocytoma
definitions_glossary.von_hippel_lindau: VHL syndrome with pheochromocytoma, renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas
definitions_glossary.succinate_dehydrogenase: SDHx mutations associated with paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas

pathophysiology.mechanism: Tumor secretion of catecholamines (norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) causing adrenergic symptoms and potentially life-threatening hypertension

catecholamine_effects.beta_1_receptor: Tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, increased cardiac output

hereditary_syndromes: MEN2A/2B (RET mutation) - bilateral pheochromocytomas, medullary thyroid cancer, hyperparathyroidism
Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) - pheochromocytoma, renal cell carcinoma, CNS hemangioblastomas
SDHx mutations (SDHA, SDHB, SDHC, SDHD) - paragangliomas, increased malignancy risk with SDHB
Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) - café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, pheochromocytoma
pathophysiology.malignancy: 10-15% malignant; defined by metastases (not histology); SDHB mutations increase malignancy risk

clinical_presentation.classic_triad: Episodic headache, sweating, palpitations (only 24% have all three)
clinical_presentation.hypertension: Sustained or paroxysmal; 50% have paroxysmal episodes
other_symptoms: Anxiety and sense of impending doom
clinical_presentation.triggers: Physical activity, tumor palpation, anesthesia, certain medications, micturition (bladder paraganglioma)

biochemical_testing.interpretation: Values >2× upper limit of normal highly suggestive; borderline values need repeat testing or clonidine suppression test
biochemical_testing.clonidine_suppression_test: Used for borderline results; catecholamines suppress >50% in false positives, not in pheo

imaging.when_to_image: ONLY after biochemical confirmation (avoid incidentaloma pitfall)
imaging.first_line: CT or MRI of adrenals (90-95% sensitivity)
imaging.functional_imaging: 123I-MIBG scan or 68Ga-DOTATATE PET for extra-adrenal, metastatic, or difficult localization

diagnostic_criteria.genetic_testing: Recommended for ALL patients regardless of family history (30-40% have germline mutations)

alpha_blockade.drug: Phenoxybenzamine (non-competitive, non-selective) 10-20 mg BID-TID, titrate to effect
alpha_blockade.goals: Blood pressure <130/80 mmHg seated, orthostatic hypotension present

beta_blockade.timing: Only AFTER adequate alpha-blockade (3-5 days after starting alpha)
beta_blockade.drug: Propranolol 20-40 mg TID-QID or atenolol 25-50 mg daily

preoperative_preparation.volume_expansion: Liberal salt and fluid intake to reverse catecholamine-induced volume contraction
preoperative_preparation.metyrosine: Catecholamine synthesis inhibitor for additional preoperative control if needed

surgical_treatment.approach: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy preferred for most tumors <6 cm
surgical_treatment.bilateral_disease: Cortical-sparing surgery considered to avoid lifelong steroid replacement
surgical_treatment.intraoperative_management: Anesthesia team must be prepared for hypertensive crisis (phentolamine, nitroprusside) and hypotension (volume, pressors) after tumor removal

malignant_disease.treatment: Surgical resection of resectable disease; MIBG therapy, chemotherapy, or tyrosine kinase inhibitors for unresectable/metastatic

treatment_options.follow_up: Lifelong surveillance with annual plasma metanephrines (recurrence/metastases can occur years later)

skos.definition: A rare catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla causing episodic hypertension and adrenergic symptoms requiring biochemical diagnosis and surgical resection with preoperative alpha-blockade

subcodes: C74.1 - Malignant neoplasm of medulla of adrenal gland

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical presentation suggestive of pheochromocytoma
Select appropriate biochemical testing (plasma free metanephrines preferred)
Explain why imaging should only be done after biochemical confirmation
Apply preoperative alpha-blockade protocol (alpha before beta)
Identify hereditary syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma
clinical_pearls: Always biochemically confirm before imaging - avoid the 'incidentaloma' trap
Plasma free metanephrines are most sensitive test (96-100%)
Alpha-blockade MUST come before beta-blockade to prevent hypertensive crisis
30-40% have germline mutations - genetic testing recommended for ALL patients
SDHB mutations carry highest malignancy risk
Bladder paragangliomas cause symptoms with micturition
Medications to avoid: tricyclics, metoclopramide, glucocorticoids (can trigger crisis)
After surgical cure, annual biochemical screening is lifelong (late recurrence possible)

step1_concepts: Alpha and beta adrenergic receptor physiology
common_questions: Patient with episodic headache, sweating, palpitations, and HTN - first test?
Why is alpha-blockade given before beta-blockade?
Adrenal incidentaloma with elevated metanephrines - next step?
